subject: Re: [junit] How to add jUnit testing to an existing large JAVA project?
msgSnippet: I d second Joel s suggestion about the book, its very good. However, given the code already exists and that Micheal s book talks about adding unit tests to new
messageBody:
I'd second Joel's suggestion about the book, its very good.

However, given the code already exists and that Micheal's book talks about
adding unit tests to new code thats added to existing code, rather than a
whole-sale retrofitting of unit tests, I'd also recommend use an automated
unit test generator.

I've only ever seen Agitar in action (other tools do exist), but it is very
good at quickly creating hundreds of unit tests for existing code, without
you having to do anything like what is described in Micheal's book.

I'm not in anyway associated with Agitar, just impressed with their tool.

Its not cheap, but then its far cheaper to buy than to hire developers to
sit there manually retrofitting unit tests.

I personally would not use it in a Test Driven Developmemt session, others
do.

Andrew


On 19/11/2007, Joel Neely <joel.neely@...> wrote:
>
> I highly recommend _Working_Effectively_with_Legacy_Code_ by Michael
> Feathers.
> (His definition of "legacy code" is simply "code without tests",
> regardless of when it
> was written, or by whom.)
>
> That book does an outstanding job of discussing how to get code under
> test.
> The first section, "The Mechanics of Change", describes goals and
> techniques
> of unit testing, along with general strategies for getting tests
> around code that
> wasn't designed to be tested. The second section, "Changing Software", is
> almost a set of case studies. Each chapter addresses a specific problem of
> the
> form, 'I need to ..." or "How do I ..." with clear suggestions and
> illustrations.
> The third section, " Dependency-Breaking Techniques", returns to the
> general
> level and presents a catalog of tactics for breaking code down into
> testable
> (and manageable) segments.
>
> I sincerely believe the best thing you could do (given your questions) is
> to
> read that book and start trying out the techniques it presents.
>
> Good luck!
>
> -jn-
>
